text:
For the final session of the C Study Group, we will be looking at the chapter from DeepR. Cohort 1 discussed the exercises (<https://deepr.gagolewski.com/chapter/310-compiled.html#exercises>) in the group session just now and we suggest the following for next time:

• Work through the questions for Exercise 14.29
• Aim to implement at least one of the functions in Exercise 14.30 with an R front end and a C back end. <@U035M81N341> and <@U04RM6HJ5GT>will implement `rle()` and  <@U060RULT44D> and me will implement `split()`. If we have a go at another one we will report back here - it would be good to have some overlap so we can compare approaches and discuss any difficulties faced.
The other exercises are useful, but may not lead to much group discussion, so we can leave these as optional extras.

text:
In Cohort 2 we noticed there are actually several exercises interweaved in the earlier sections! The earlier exercises are more closely connected to the content in each section, so are a bit more like the exercises we have been used to so far, but without the skeleton code and hints :sweat_smile: I've had a closer look and I think the following may be an equivalent amount of work to the lab + practice problems on the CS50 course:

Exercise 14.1 : inspect and load demo R package with C code
Exercise 14.2 : extend the package by adding a C function equivalent to which.max()
Exercise 14.3 : compile some of the demo C functions and write an R function to use them
Exercise 14.4 : implement all() and any() in C.

There are then several more exercises that work with lists, factors and matrices among other things, even before you get to the Exercises section I linked to before. We might want to come back to these exercises in July/August as I think most of us won't be able to have a decent go at these in June. How does that sound?
